questions.question_text:
You have several computers that run Windows 10. The computers are in a workgroup and have BitLocker Drive Encryption (BitLocker) enabled.
You join the computers to Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You need to ensure that you can recover the BitLocker recovery key for the computers from Azure AD.
What should you do first?

comments.content: If your machine is already encrypted and joined to Azure AD, you can run "manage-bde.exe -protectors -aadbackup C: -id {Your Bitlocker recovery key ID}" and it will backup the recovery key to azure without any issue. I just tested this on my machine. Answer B is correct.

discussion.content: "manage-bde.exe -protectors -aadbackup" is the command to throw the keus it to Azure AD

Regarding the docs you should first run the command for adding keyprotector. Not after the device is encrypted. So in that case it should be A.https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/information-protection/bitlocker/bitlocker-management-for-enterprises#powershell-examples

Aは間違っている。
無効にしたあと、有効にする必要がある。
無効にしただけでは達成できない。

Selected Answer: B
The correct answer is B. Add a BitLocker key protector.

To ensure that you can recover the BitLocker recovery key for the computers from Azure AD after joining them to Azure AD, you should add a BitLocker key protector. A BitLocker key protector is a way to store a copy of the BitLocker recovery key in a safe location, such as Azure AD, which can be used to recover the drive in case of a hardware failure or other issue.
again wrong answer. diable and enable bitlocker
You create the key protector, then you upload it to Azure AD.

Not completely official: https://campbell.scot/store-bitlocker-recovery-keys-in-azure-ad-for-devices-already-encrypted/. Seems to suggest you can do this without disabling bitlocker. B is the best answer.

comments.content: Agreed. B is the best answer. Especially after reviewing the microsoft document attached to the answer.

discussion.content: Well - I can only see B as an option, the other three answers are completely nonsense?
Essa questão ficou muito dividida no gabarito, afinal qual seria a resposta e qual a justificativa? Após um debate de 9 comentários, o gabarito é o mesmo ou não?

B. seems like the best option
https://www.windowscentral.com/how-use-bitlocker-encryption-windows-10
Control Panel\All Control Panel Items\BitLocker Drive Encryption Backup your recovery keys
In general, the number one is correct. You can test it on your own.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/manage-bde-protectors

comments.content:
Okay, as per Topic 2 Q32 the following group policies need to be enabled for Bitlocker encryption:

Require additional authentication at startup
Configure how Bitlocker protected OS drives can be recovered

discussion.content: To save the encryption key to Azure AD, the only thing you need to do is log in using an Azure account. The recovery key would be backed up to Azure.

I can't find anything to back this up but I think this is wrong. I think the only way you can escrow those keys is to disable BitLocker and then re-enable. So the first step would be to disable BitLocker.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have two workgroup computers named Computer1 and Computer2 that run Windows 10. The computers contain the local security principals shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Which security principals can be members of GroupA and GroupC? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: Group nesting here means that a group cannot be a member of another here I think. Thats what I got to know by testing.

discussion.content: Sorry, group nesting is not possible locally.
Group A: User1 and Group B. Or tell me why not.

comments.content: Default is correct: It's not possible to apply a group policy to a security group . However, you can change the permissions on group policy so that only certain users/groups have read and apply privileges.

choices.B: Install the latest feature updates on the computer.
choices.C: Upgrade the computer to Windows 10 Enterprise.
choices.A: Register the computer to Azure AD.
choices.D: Upgrade the computer to Windows 10 Pro.

comments.content: Can confirm Home -> Pro -> Enterprise is the proper stages according to official Microsoft MD-100 study material (which doesn't have very much... almost like Microsoft is trying to make us pay for $2000 course or other books)
You cannot upgrade Home to Enterprise directly, need to upgrade to Pro first.

Agree. However, why not upgrade to Enterprise instead of Pro? Windows devices in Azure are usually Windows 10 Enterprise devices as (only) Enterprise can get automatically distributed through the Azure licensing (which can't be done with Pro).

discussion.content:
You need to upgrade to Windows 10 Pro, because Windows 10 Home can not join to Azure AD 
 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/answers/questions/35017/how-to-azure-ad-join-a-windows-10-home-device.html

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is D. Upgrade the computer to Windows 10 Pro.

To ensure that the user can use the fingerprint reader to sign in to the computer by using an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) account on a computer that has Windows 10 Home preinstalled, you need to upgrade the computer to Windows 10 Pro. The ability to join a computer to Azure AD and use biometric authentication for sign-in is available only in Windows 10 Pro and Enterprise editions.

Selected Answer: A
Chat-GPT
A. Register the computer to Azure AD should be done first to ensure that the user can use the fingerprint reader to sign in to the computer by using an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) account.

Once the computer is registered to Azure AD, the user can set up Windows Hello for Business to enable biometric authentication for Azure AD users on the device. This will allow the user to sign in to the device using their Azure AD account and biometric authentication (fingerprint reader).

Installing the latest feature updates and upgrading to Windows 10 Enterprise or Windows 10 Pro are not necessary for this scenario. However, it's important to ensure that the computer is running a version of Windows 10 that supports Windows Hello for Business and biometric authentication, which Windows 10 Home does support.

comments.content:
Lesson here is don't trust chat GPT?

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/devices/concept-azure-ad-join#:~:text=You%20can%20configure%20Azure%20AD%20join%20for%20all%20Windows%2011%20and%20Windows%2010%20devices%20except%20for%20Home%20editions.

Can Windows 10 Home edition be joined to Azure AD ?

Yes, Windows 10 Home edition can be joined to Azure AD, but it has some limitations. Windows 10 Home edition can only join Azure AD as a Workgroup Joined device, which means that it will not have access to all of the features and management capabilities that are available to devices that are joined to Azure AD as a domain-joined device.

However, by joining a Windows 10 Home device to Azure AD, users can still use their Azure AD credentials to sign in to the device and access resources that are protected by Azure AD, such as Azure AD-joined web applications and services.

To join a Windows 10 Home device to Azure AD, the user must navigate to the Settings app, select the "Accounts" category, and then select "Access work or school." From there, the user can add their Azure AD account and follow the prompts to complete the enrollment process.

questions.question_text:
A user purchases a new computer that has Windows 10 Home preinstalled. The computer has a biometric fingerprint reader.
You need to ensure that the user can use the fingerprint reader to sign in to the computer by using an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) account.
What should you do first?

discussion.content: I agree!

no no yes is the correct answer 

If Computer1 initiates communication to Computer2, network traffic will NOT be encrypted because the connection security rule on Computer2 does not require authentication.

Computer2 cannot establish communication to Computer3 because the connection security rule on Computer3 requires inbound authentication, which Computer2 does not provide.

If Computer3 initiates communication to Computer1, network traffic will be encrypted because the connection security rule on Computer1 requires inbound authentication, which Computer3 provides.

Answer is correct, NO NO YES. Keyword here is:
"All the connection security rules are enabled and configured to use only the Computer (Kerberos V5) authentication method."

And Kerberos has data encryption implied 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/security-policy-settings/network-security-configure-encryption-types-allowed-for-kerberos

Correct answers: NO NO NO

Server-to-server - Authenticate connection between the specified computers.
Do Not Authenticate - No connections will be authenticated.

Inbound connections must be authenticated to be allowed. Outbound connections are authenticated whenever possible but authentication is not required.

comments.content:
First NO

Traffic will not be encrypted by default. The question does not have this option configured by default. Encryption is optional, not default to authentications. Encryption needs to be enabled in the GPO. The default is data integrity which is not default to encrypt. Actually, if you encrypt you will use both integrity with encryption.

Devices in the encryption zone require authentication to communicate with other devices.

Third NO

No, it will not encrypt. Encryption is not enabled by default. Data integrity is default.

Second NO

As Computer3 has require inbound, and require inbound must be authenticated to be allowed, then there is no connection because Computer3 will not allow it.

discussion.content: Looks right.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
Your network contains an Active Directory domain. The domain contains three computers named Computer1, Computer2, and Computer3 that run Windows 10.
The computers are on the same network and have network connectivity.
Windows Defender Firewall on Computer1 has the server-to-server connection security rule shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Windows Defender Firewall on Computer2 has the server-to-server connection security rule shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Windows Defender Firewall on Computer3 has the server-to-server connection security rule shown in the following table.
//IMG//

All the connection security rules are enabled and configured to use only the Computer (Kerberos V5) authentication method.
For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: seems to be correct

comments.content:
Windows reads the user-specific Local Group Policy object last; therefore, it has the highest precedence. The Local Computer Policy has lowered precedence.

@Examtopics Why so many wrong answers???

discussion.content:
3 = YES
 Local Computer\Non-Administrators Policy  Remove Recycle Bin icon = Enable
 Computer policy  Remove Recycle Bin icon = Disable
If we set the settings conflicts with each other in Computer Configuration and User Configuration in one GPO, the Computer configuration will override the User Configuration.

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: No -
The Desktop Wallpaper setting in the Local Computer\Non-Administrators Policy specifies the path to the wallpaper image. Therefore, User1 will not be able to change the wallpaper.

Box 2: Yes -
The Remove Recycle Bin from desktop setting in the Local Computer\Administrators Policy is Not Configured which means it will not overwrite the setting in the
Local Computer Policy. The Remove Recycle Bin from desktop setting in the Local Computer Policy is Disabled. Therefore, the Recycle Bin icon is not removed.
In other words, it will be visible on the desktop.

Box 3: No -
The Remove Recycle Bin from desktop setting in the Local Computer\Non-Administrators Policy is enabled. Therefore, the Recycle Bin will be removed for User1.
